a tool for identifying redox-active disulphides from structures

Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

Intermolecular
Cysteine 895 and cysteine 55 of Sodium channel subunit beta-2
Cysteine 903 and cysteine 55 of Sodium channel subunit beta-2
Cysteine 1185 and cysteine 181 of Sodium channel subunit beta-1
Cysteine 897 and cysteine 55 of Sodium channel subunit beta-2
Intramolecular
Cysteine 315 and cysteine 330
Cysteine 897 and cysteine 903
Cysteine 1715 and cysteine 1730
Cysteine 935 and cysteine 944
Cysteine 1350 and cysteine 1370
Cysteine 324 and cysteine 330
More...
Cysteine 315 and cysteine 324
Cysteine 275 and cysteine 324
Cysteine 275 and cysteine 330
Cysteine 895 and cysteine 903
Cysteine 275 and cysteine 315
Cysteine 895 and cysteine 897
Cysteine 895 and cysteine 935

7xmf A 895 C 55

A redox-regulated disulphide may form between Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha and Sodium channel subunit beta-2 at these cysteines.

Relevent regions

Does not bind alpha subunit. Loss of ability to protect alpha subunit from inhibition by the spider protoxin-II.

78.54
PDB code
7xmf
Structure name
cryo-em structure of human nav1.7/beta1/beta2-nav1.7-in2
Structure deposition date
2022-04-25

Peptide A name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

Sodium channel subunit beta-2
Peptide A accession

Peptide B accession

Peptide A residue number
895
Peptide B residue number
55

7xmg A 903 F 55

A redox-regulated disulphide may form between Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha and Sodium channel subunit beta-2 at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Relevent regions

Does not bind alpha subunit. Loss of ability to protect alpha subunit from inhibition by the spider protoxin-II.

variation residue

Redox score
65.67
PDB code
7xmg
Structure name
cryo-em structure of human nav1.7/beta1/beta2-tcn-1752
Structure deposition date
2022-04-25
Thiol separation (Å)
8.67
Half-sphere exposure sum
46
Minimum pKa
nan
% buried
nan
Peptide A name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha
Peptide B name
Sodium channel subunit beta-2
Peptide A accession
Q15858
Peptide B accession
O60939
Peptide A residue number
903
Peptide B residue number
55

7xve A 1185 B 181

A redox-regulated disulphide may form between Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha and Sodium channel subunit beta-1 at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Relevent regions

In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift in channel activation, a depolarizing shift of inactivation and an 18-fold increase in deactivation time compared to wild-type; the mean ramp current amplitude in response to slow depolarization is higher in the mutant channels; dbSNP:rs80356476.

181

7w9l A 897 C 55

A redox-regulated disulphide may form between Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha and Sodium channel subunit beta-2 at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Relevent regions

Does not bind alpha subunit. Loss of ability to protect alpha subunit from inhibition by the spider protoxin-II.

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7w9k A 897 A 903

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

B
In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7w9l A 1715 A 1730

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

Relevent regions

In CIP; significant reduction in membrane localization of the mutant protein compared to the wild-type; complete loss of function of the sodium channel.

In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7xm9 A 935 A 944

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7xmf A 1350 A 1370

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

Relevent regions

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7w9l A 324 A 330

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

In PEPD; dbSNP:rs121908910.
original residue
R
variation residue
C
position
1007
score
100.0
distance
84.47801
seq distance
677
chain
A
In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.
original residue
Q
variation residue
R
position
10
score
72.72727272727273
distance
88.542114
seq distance
314
chain
A
In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7w9k A 315 A 324

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

Relevent regions

In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.

Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7xmg A 275 A 324

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines.

Peptide accession

Residue number A

Residue number B
324
Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7w9t A 275 A 330

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Relevent regions

A
In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.

Structure name
cryo-em structure of human nav1.7(e406k) in complex with auxiliary beta subunits, huwentoxin-iv and saxitoxin (s6iv alpha helix conformer)
Structure deposition date
2021-12-10
Thiol separation (Å)
6.56
Half-sphere exposure sum
70
Minimum pKa
nan
% buried
nan
Peptide accession
Q15858
Residue number A
275
Residue number B
330
Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7xmf A 895 A 903

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Relevent regions

Peptide accession

Residue number A

Residue number B
903
Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7xmg A 275 A 315

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Relevent regions

Peptide accession

Residue number A

Residue number B
315
Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7xm9 A 895 A 897

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

Residue number B
897
Peptide name
Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha

7w9m A 895 A 935

A redox-regulated disulphide may form within Sodium channel protein type 9 subunit alpha at these cysteines. However, the redox score of this cysteine pair is lower than any known redox-active disulphide.

In PERYTHM; causes a hyperpolarizing shift of -5.3 mV for the midpoint of activation which is smaller than that seen in other mutations causing early-onset erythromelalgia mutations; also causes a faster rate of activation and slower deactivation compared to wild-type; expression of the mutant protein induced hyperexcitability in dorsal root ganglion neurons but the increase is smaller than that produced by Thr-859; dbSNP:rs267607030.
